title: MapleBR Private Server
learnings: A good way to learn how to code is by testing things made by others
problem: I needed to practice what I've studied at the University so I started to learn by reading and running open source codes from the internet.
solution: I built a custom MapleStory private server for testing and learning purposes. I used to code in Java for backend (hosted on a Windows Server 2008), PHP and MySQL to create the page for people to signup. You can see my first page if you read the 3-3-3 Principle.
label: maplestory

title: SIGUP - System for Public Expenses Data Management
subtitle: Departamento de √Åguas e Energia El√©trica
learnings: You can find how to improve a system by observing final user's daily work
problem: Public Expenses Data were all managed by EXCEL spreadsheets, turning it difficult to be maintained and shared.
solution: I suggested the team to build a centralized database for data management in PHP and MySQL. We researched, prototyped, developed our solution translating spreadsheets and graphics into a centralized dashboard with charts (Google Charts API). The results were an economy of R$200.000 (approx. U$50.000 at that time) in public expenses in 6 years.
label: sigup

title: Bingo Screen for Matsuri Events
learnings: Anything can be used for years if it solves a problem. Even if it's a Web page
problem: We always used a whiteboard to display Bingo Game numbers on our Matsuri Events
solution: I built a simple SPA in HTML and JQuery to display bingo numbers for our events. It needed to display big-sized numbers because of the elder public. We kept using it at every Matsuri that had bingo prizes. You can try it as well clicking on the link below!
label: bingo

title: Automatic Public Expenses Bills Email Sender
subtitle: Departamento de √Åguas e Energia El√©trica
learnings: Everyone has a browser in their pockets so we can reach anyone with JS
problem: The public expenses bills from 50+ locations were sent to a centralized building. We needed to send the right bills to the right places by e-mail.
solution: I built a simple tool in NodeJS to help my colleagues send their emails.
label: mailer

title: Event Cashier Manager with Barcode Reader
learnings: Sometimes, the solution needs to do only one thing better than the others.
problem: We imported products from Hokkaido and needed a free solution to manage products, stocks and orders for our Bussanten event.
solution: Using Cloud Firestore as Backend, it was easy to create a system that registers products, orders and only other necessary info for that occasion. I researched, modeled data structure and built the system using ReactJS and Firebase BaaS.
label: cashier

title: Admin Dashboard for Startup Operations
subtitle: Noli Fretes - STARTUP
learnings: Prototyping and MVPing at the same time made me think: There must be a lot of UI/UX opportunities out there
problem: We had a MVP Backend and a mobile APP in production so we needed a functional admin interface
solution: I researched the needs, sketched the screens and started building the features by priority order. I created the auth system, CRUD interfaces, and a dashboard for tracking trucks with GoogleMaps.
label: noli

title: Financial Management Spreadsheet with Web Interface
learnings: How to create a web application, build and host it for free?
problem: All financial data from the Association were in an Excel Sheet. They needed an easier way to register information and print monthly balances.
solution: I converted the .XLS sheet into a Google Spreadsheet, served it's data via Google Apps Scripts http request and made this system in ReactJS. It became a complete dashboard for controlling incomes and expenses.
label: aliber

title: Personal Financial Dashboard for My Exchange Time in Japan
learnings: You can create a habit if you facilitate the behavior to happen more often
problem: Manage daily personal finances during exchange program in Hokkaido.
solution: During the 14 days of quarantine period, I built a tool to input daily finances data on a Google Sheets. It was an Google Sheet serving data to a SPA in ReactJS. I created the simplest and easiest input form so I could use it on daily basis. I used that simple interface every time I bought something during my exchange program and the results were a full cash control, input anytime/anywhere, and more learnings
label: jpn-utils

title: Tutorial Blog for ROS and Drone control
learnings: Research ROS and Internet Of Things - IoT - in Japan
public: Robot Operating System - ROS - University Students
problem: Practice Web development and explaining skills while doing an Exchange Program
solution: Built a Blog alike tutorial for ROS and Drone control. In order to build it, I was introduced to tools like NextJS, i18n for internationalization, and GSAP for animating elements. It was a test project and I learned a lot about how to dominate the DOM. It was a practice in English writing as well.
label: ros

title: Ecoid.com.br Institutional Website
learnings: The cleaner it is, better for the user
public: Restaurant Owners who works with food delivery
problem: The client got an opportunity to represent sales from a paper bowls manufacturer and needed a website to start prospecting.
solution: I built a simple SPA with a cleaner design. It worked fine at the beginning but, a few months later, the client gave up on the business. It was my first time using TailwindCSS and it made CSS styling really fast. It was when I started to use Design and Prototyping tools like Illustrator and XD
label: ecoid

title: Hokkaido Association Ishikari Nabe Event Promotional Landing Page [Page for Mobile]
learnings: A good UX makes users stay on your screen and take actions, whatever the action is
problem: It was our first event after one year of covid pandemics and we needed to present a new plate to the public
solution: I was in charge of making a page to introduce our event to the public. This time I focused on the page interactivity and on SVG animations. We sent the page on Whatsapp groups, and approx. 50% of all conversions came from our page, and the other 50% came directly from whatsapp or personal contact. I learned a lot about getting the audience attention, lead them to an educational content about the product and then, to let them take an action.
label: ishikari

title: Gustavo Amaral's NFT Collection Landing Page
subtitle: WeDoIT.jp
learnings: "It is not necessary to understand everything to be able to use everything"
problem: Find a good way to launch an NFT Collection
solution: We built a landing page for promoting an NFT Collection from an artist friend. We  promoted it compiling information about the artist and his previous works. The challenge here was to translate the artist's style into an animated Webpage.
label: gustavo-amaral

title: Onoda Boeki Internationalized Website and Logo Design
subtitle: WeDoIT.jp
public: People interested in importing products from Japan to Brazil
problem: The client needed a website and a logo for his business
solution: Me and my friend researched, designed and built a single page institutional Website for the company and it's logo as well.
label: onoda

title: This Portfolio and the 3-3-3 Principles For a Better UX
subtitle: WeDoIT.jp
learnings: Keep reading to know me better
public: Recruiters, Developers studying UI/UX and future partners
problem: Expose my experiences in a clear way to explain how I can help in new projects and teams
solution: This portfolio is a compilation of what I've done and what I've learned in order to be an UI/UX Developer. The 3-3-3 Principles For A Better UX is a guide for you to understand, learn and apply the fundamentals in your next works!
label: portfolio
